title: Crystal ball would have helped on takeover: APA chairman
text:
APA Group chairman Michael Fraser has defended the board's decision last year to recommend the $13 billion takeover proposal from CKI Group, saying the fall in global interest rates that has since propelled the gas pipeline owner's share price past the offer price was unexpected.

Mr Fraser said the question as to why the board supported the Hong Kong-based group's $11 a share offer was "very fair" but noted that it offered a premium of 30-35 per cent above the trading price of APA's shares at the time of below $8.40.

"At the time, we weren’t anticipating the fall in global interest rates that has since occurred and which has been a significant driver behind APA’s increased security price over the last 10 months," Mr Fraser told the annual shareholder meeting in Sydney on Thursday.

APA Group is forecasting another year of earnings growth. Supplied

"We, like most people at that time, expected interest rates to rise over the medium to long term – a scenario which we would not have expected to be positive for our security price."

He said the board had based its decision on what it believed were the best interests of shareholders based on information and forecasts, but that "clearly a crystal ball would be helpful in this respect".
description: The board of the gas pipeline owner wasn't expecting the fall in global interest rates at the time it backed CKI's takeover offer, Michael Fraser says.
